The oldest fossils found on this planet are over three billions years of age- and they reveal very complex bacteria- I remember reading something like full on RNA, and around four thousand separate parts- and so the question is, how did we get from some amino acids and precursor chemicals to a full living organism? Science has always assumed evolution, but there is a small group within the microbiology community that believes that isn't possible in the time between the formation of the Earth and the oldest fossils. It has been recently revealed that some sixty tons of dust fall from space to the surface of Earth each and every day. 90% of it comes from within the solar system, but about 10% is interstellar- originating from other places within the galaxy. Chances are that some very small amount of that 10% originates from other galaxies- and so it's certainly possible that the very first life on this planet did not evolve here, or even evolve within the solar system- but that it arrived here from somewhere else in the Milky Way. It will be very interesting to see precisely what life we do find in other parts of the solar system, and exactly what it has in common with life here- because if it is similar enough (say, the presence of RNA) than that will potentially be a step toward proving that all life has an interstellar origin... meaning that there is life quite literally everywhere across the galaxy, and also across the universe. I have always felt that the question, "Are we alone in the universe?" epitomizes human hubris, the obvious answer being, "Of course not.". One need look only at the proven existence of extremophile bacteria to make that conclusion...

Life always finds a way: https://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/Bacteria-found-in-Hanford-waste-1145677.php One of the more interesting aspects of this discovery is that nuclear enrichment produces radioactive isotopes that have never been found to exist in nature- this proves that these organisms were able to evolve defenses that protect them from some of the most extreme radioactive and toxic substances known to exist anywhere on Earth. It would seem to me that the environment in a subterranean ocean on Europa would be more hospitable to life than in the contaminated soil beneath a leaking nuclear waste storage container.
